fields.headline: ELT Diary
fields.bodyText: Japan action plan Japan's education ministry has committed itself to reform proposals laid out last year by publishing an action plan to improve national English skills. The goals include teaching the majority of English-language classes at middle and high schools in English and to send 10,000 high school students overseas as exchange students annually by 2008. Meanwhile a language school in Osaka has developed an English course based on rakugo, traditional Japanese comedy routines, according to the Nikkei Weekly. Kaishi Katsura, a rakugo performer who is developing the course for EEC school said, "Rakugo, in which we listen with our ears and imitate with our mouths, is similar to foreign-language study." Innovation winners The winners of the British Council's UK ELT Innovation Awards were announced last month. The three joint prizes went to Warwick University's Listening To Lectures CD-Rom, aimed at helping foreign students prepare for the varied style of delivery of British academics, and featuring lecturer and author Germaine Greer. BBC Worldwide's Goal multimedia package was selected for mixing a TV-soap format, sport and study. Flo-Joe, a website offering revision tips for the Cambridge English-language exams, was the third winner. Malaysia training Twenty thousand maths and science teachers in Malaysia who are due to start teaching the subjects in English will be sent for training and special courses this year, according to Malaysia's national news agency. The move to English-medium teaching in selected subjects is part of a government initiative aimed at creating a globally competitive workforce. Dutch recruitment The Netherlands has opened an education recruitment office in Hong Kong to provide information about the 650 higher education programmes taught in English in the Netherlands. max.delotbiniere@theguardian.com
